The game could really use some more instruction on what you can do, as a couple of levels had me clicking randomly because I had no idea what my goal was--particularly the 'mirror' level, which I had no idea I could move the mirror, which told you what the layout should be. It's a great shame there aren't more kinetic puzzles like the finale, which ended the game beautifully after some repeated gimmick tedium.

Over all, a decent purchase on sale if you like busy work to pass the time. It's not really a "clean up" game, it's more about pattern recognition and symmetry. By far my favourite levels were the drawers, where you arrange random objects like a jigsaw puzzle. This game isn't much fun. Theoretically it has a lot going for it - pleasant graphics, relaxing music, puzzles, sorting, and a cat. However, the puzzles are fiddly in an annoying way. There might be multiple solutions to one puzzle, but within the solutions, there isn't much flexibility. For example, you got that you have to order something by size or number, but only one way (left to right, top to down) counts, not right to left or bottom up. Sometimes, your solutions have to be pixel-perfect, so that you actually sorted everything correctly, just two pixles too far right. Therefore "A little to the left" has to be taken literally and this slight readjustment of correct solutions becomes an annoying trial-and-error assignment far too often.

I also encountered some bugs (e.g. in the Archives with the extendable tool drawer - one of the puzzle pieces got stuck to the drawer and could not be picked up again), which made the game feel really tedious. It is fun in concept, but the execution leaves too much room for frustration as the difficulty is not finding patterns, but adjusting the objects in hopes you found the right spot for it to count.

I’m only giving this game a negative rating because people deserve to see the honest cons—I actually really enjoyed it. It’s a great, relaxing puzzle game with a unique atmosphere, but the bugs (especially in Chapter 5) really hold it back. Some of these issues have been reported on the community tab for over a year without fixes, and the devs seem more focused on releasing DLCs than addressing long-standing problems. When a bug hits, the only “solution” is restarting the level until it decides to work, which gets frustrating fast.

If the bugs were resolved, this would easily be a positive review from me.

I have never encountered a game that overstays its welcome more than A Little to the Left. This is a "puzzle" game (I use that term somewhat loosely; I don't think the game is really the next Baba is You, nor is it trying to be) about arranging objects neatly. If, like I had, you've seen footage of the game, you've probably seen a lot of nice clips of people tidying up drawers of utensils or aligning stationery in a satisfying way.

And the game does have those levels. If the game [i]just[/i] had those levels, I'd probably like it a lot more. But those levels are somewhat few and far between, and a lot of the content that makes up the rest of the game just doesn't really work for me. There are some decent ones - some levels later in the game play with ideas of symmetry, which are fun. A lot of levels, though, amount to "arrange these six objects by height", with an optional bonus objective for also arranging them by colour or something like that. These levels are such blatant filler and I have little good to say about them. A Little to the Left isn't trying to be a super complex puzzle game, but it'd still be nice if I had to think hard enough to be paying more attention to it than whatever I'm watching on my second monitor.

The worst offenders, however, are what I'll call the nonsense levels: levels where the solution isn't clear at all, and might not even become apparent after you've solved it. The final set of base game levels has a lot of these more experimental ideas, and often they just make no sense. For example, in one level you're presented with a set of hanging picture frames you can tilt, and eventually have to surmise that you have to get a ball in one painting into a hole another by tilting the frames so it rolls. But even once you work that out, which frame the ball will go to next isn't obvious, because they're not aligned, and so it just becomes a tedious process of trial and error. There's no "aha" moment like you'd want from a good puzzle.

The absolute worst level for this is the calendar level you encounter very early in the game. I have beaten this twice (achievements required two full playthroughs) and I still have no idea what the solution was. You have to put stickers on a calendar. I thought it'd be the case that each sticker would follow patterns on the grid, and for the most part they did, but some couldn't go where they would need to in order to continue the pattern, so it wasn't clear where else they should be. I eventually just resorted to trying each sticker in every square until I heard the audio cue for a correct placement. I'm probably missing something obvious, but that's also kind of besides the point when this game is marketed as "the satisfying drawer arranging game". There is at least a hint system - though they're less so "hints" than just reveals of the solution - as well as the option to skip levels entirely. Be aware, however, using these at all locks you out of achievements, which is why my second playthrough was necessitated.

The satisfying drawer arranging levels are good. I want to make that clear. The DLCs especially are a bit more focused on those kinds of levels, often with less obvious places for things to go (early game ones can be a bit simplistic because the spoon goes in the spoon-shaped hole, and so on), so some trial and error (the good kind) is required. That said, the second DLC also goes a lot harder on the obtuse stuff where you have to read the devs' minds to get the solution to trigger. Often I'd find the solution but not fulfil some arbitrary second requirement (at times, I'm not even sure if these requirements were intended) and have to just randomly move things around. For example, one level had one solution where you had to pull plants out of their pots and check the lengths of their roots, then arrange them by root length. When I did this, the solution didn't trigger, and so I ended up swapping plants into different pots until it did. As far as I could tell, there was no logic or pattern to the pots each plant was in when the solution triggered. I have no idea if I was missing something or if it's completely arbitrary due to some kind of oversight.

The problem with this game is just that satisfying drawer arranging really only has so much mileage. And rather than just make a small game focused on that concept, A Little to the Left is padded out with a bunch of levels which stretch its gimmick and wear it incredibly thin. I think the best way to sum the game up is its daily challenges. I normally wait until I've 100%ed a game before I review it (because I think you can only really give a fair review of something once you've experienced all of it and Steam achievements are usually a solid benchmark for what "all the content" entails). However, I'm still missing 9 achievements for A Little to the Left. I've played all the base game and DLC content, but those 9 achievements are for the game's daily challenges. Every day, the game wants you to solve one of its puzzles (and these puzzles are, at best, slightly tweaked versions of existing levels, there's nothing fundamentally new about them if you've played the base game). This game does not merit playing daily. It's not interesting enough for me to want to sign onto it every day. But it seems to think it is, because it has achievements for doing so for 100 days.

A Little to the Left has a misplaced confidence in its own quality. The total cost of this game and its DLCs, outside of a sale, is £25. And its gimmick simply does not have the legs to support the number of puzzles required to justify that price tag. If this game were £10, and it was just the puzzles that are actually good, I'd love it. This is a "puzzle" game (I use that term somewhat loosely; I don't think the game is really the next Baba is You, nor is it trying to be) about arranging objects neatly. And the game does have those levels. If the game [i]just[/i] had those levels, I'd probably like it a lot more. But those levels are somewhat few and far between, and a lot of the content that makes up the rest of the game just doesn't really work for me. There are some decent ones - some levels later in the game play with ideas of symmetry, which are fun. A lot of levels, though, amount to "arrange these six objects by height", with an optional bonus objective for also arranging them by colour or something like that. These levels are such blatant filler and I have little good to say about them. A Little to the Left isn't trying to be a super complex puzzle game, but it'd still be nice if I had to think hard enough to be paying more attention to it than whatever I'm watching on my second monitor.

The worst offenders, however, are what I'll call the nonsense levels: levels where the solution isn't clear at all, and might not even become apparent after you've solved it. The final set of base game levels has a lot of these more experimental ideas, and often they just make no sense. For example, in one level you're presented with a set of hanging picture frames you can tilt, and eventually have to surmise that you have to get a ball in one painting into a hole another by tilting the frames so it rolls. But even once you work that out, which frame the ball will go to next isn't obvious, because they're not aligned, and so it just becomes a tedious process of trial and error. There's no "aha" moment like you'd want from a good puzzle.

The absolute worst level for this is the calendar level you encounter very early in the game. I have beaten this twice (achievements required two full playthroughs) and I still have no idea what the solution was. You have to put stickers on a calendar. I thought it'd be the case that each sticker would follow patterns on the grid, and for the most part they did, but some couldn't go where they would need to in order to continue the pattern, so it wasn't clear where else they should be. I eventually just resorted to trying each sticker in every square until I heard the audio cue for a correct placement. I'm probably missing something obvious, but that's also kind of besides the point when this game is marketed as "the satisfying drawer arranging game". There is at least a hint system - though they're less so "hints" than just reveals of the solution - as well as the option to skip levels entirely. Be aware, however, using these at all locks you out of achievements, which is why my second playthrough was necessitated.

The satisfying drawer arranging levels are good. I want to make that clear. The DLCs especially are a bit more focused on those kinds of levels, often with less obvious places for things to go (early game ones can be a bit simplistic because the spoon goes in the spoon-shaped hole, and so on), so some trial and error (the good kind) is required. That said, the second DLC also goes a lot harder on the obtuse stuff where you have to read the devs' minds to get the solution to trigger. Often I'd find the solution but not fulfil some arbitrary second requirement (at times, I'm not even sure if these requirements were intended) and have to just randomly move things around. For example, one level had one solution where you had to pull plants out of their pots and check the lengths of their roots, then arrange them by root length. When I did this, the solution didn't trigger, and so I ended up swapping plants into different pots until it did. As far as I could tell, there was no logic or pattern to the pots each plant was in when the solution triggered. I have no idea if I was missing something or if it's completely arbitrary due to some kind of oversight.

The problem with this game is just that satisfying drawer arranging really only has so much mileage. And rather than just make a small game focused on that concept, A Little to the Left is padded out with a bunch of levels which stretch its gimmick and wear it incredibly thin. I think the best way to sum the game up is its daily challenges. I normally wait until I've 100%ed a game before I review it (because I think you can only really give a fair review of something once you've experienced all of it and Steam achievements are usually a solid benchmark for what "all the content" entails). However, I'm still missing 9 achievements for A Little to the Left. I've played all the base game and DLC content, but those 9 achievements are for the game's daily challenges. Every day, the game wants you to solve one of its puzzles (and these puzzles are, at best, slightly tweaked versions of existing levels, there's nothing fundamentally new about them if you've played the base game). This game does not merit playing daily. It's not interesting enough for me to want to sign onto it every day. But it seems to think it is, because it has achievements for doing so for 100 days.

A Little to the Left has a misplaced confidence in its own quality. The total cost of this game and its DLCs, outside of a sale, is £25. And its gimmick simply does not have the legs to support the number of puzzles required to justify that price tag. If this game were £10, and it was just the puzzles that are actually good, I'd love it. But for what it actually is - a lot of disappointing filler padding out the diamonds in the rough - there are much better indie games to spend that amount of money on.

I have never encountered a game that overstays its welcome more than A Little to the Left. This is a "puzzle" game (I use that term somewhat loosely; I don't think the game is really the next Baba is You, nor is it trying to be) about arranging objects neatly. If, like I had, you've seen footage of the game, you've probably seen a lot of nice clips of people tidying up drawers of utensils or aligning stationery in a satisfying way.

And the game does have those levels. If the game [i]just[/i] had those levels, I'd probably like it a lot more. But those levels are somewhat few and far between, and a lot of the content that makes up the rest of the game just doesn't really work for me. There are some decent ones - some levels later in the game play with ideas of symmetry, which are fun. A lot of levels, though, amount to "arrange these six objects by height", with an optional bonus objective for also arranging them by colour or something like that. These levels are such blatant filler and I have little good to say about them. A Little to the Left isn't trying to be a super complex puzzle game, but it'd still be nice if I had to think hard enough to be paying more attention to it than whatever I'm watching on my second monitor.

The worst offenders, however, are what I'll call the nonsense levels: levels where the solution isn't clear at all, and might not even become apparent after you've solved it. The final set of base game levels has a lot of these more experimental ideas, and often they just make no sense. For example, in one level you're presented with a set of hanging picture frames you can tilt, and eventually have to surmise that you have to get a ball in one painting into a hole another by tilting the frames so it rolls. But even once you work that out, which frame the ball will go to next isn't obvious, because they're not aligned, and so it just becomes a tedious process of trial and error. There's no "aha" moment like you'd want from a good puzzle.

The absolute worst level for this is the calendar level you encounter very early in the game. I have beaten this twice (achievements required two full playthroughs) and I still have no idea what the solution was. You have to put stickers on a calendar. I thought it'd be the case that each sticker would follow patterns on the grid, and for the most part they did, but some couldn't go where they would need to in order to continue the pattern, so it wasn't clear where else they should be. I eventually just resorted to trying each sticker in every square until I heard the audio cue for a correct placement. I'm probably missing something obvious, but that's also kind of besides the point when this game is marketed as "the satisfying drawer arranging game". There is at least a hint system - though they're less so "hints" than just reveals of the solution - as well as the option to skip levels entirely. Be aware, however, using these at all locks you out of achievements, which is why my second playthrough was necessitated.

The satisfying drawer arranging levels are good. I want to make that clear. The DLCs especially are a bit more focused on those kinds of levels, often with less obvious places for things to go (early game ones can be a bit simplistic because the spoon goes in the spoon-shaped hole, and so on), so some trial and error (the good kind) is required. That said, the second DLC also goes a lot harder on the obtuse stuff where you have to read the devs' minds to get the solution to trigger. Often I'd find the solution but not fulfil some arbitrary second requirement (at times, I'm not even sure if these requirements were intended) and have to just randomly move things around. For example, one level had one solution where you had to pull plants out of their pots and check the lengths of their roots, then arrange them by root length. When I did this, the solution didn't trigger, and so I ended up swapping plants into different pots until it did. As far as I could tell, there was no logic or pattern to the pots each plant was in when the solution triggered. I have no idea if I was missing something or if it's completely arbitrary due to some kind of oversight.

The problem with this game is just that satisfying drawer arranging really only has so much mileage. And rather than just make a small game focused on that concept, A Little to the Left is padded out with a bunch of levels which stretch its gimmick and wear it incredibly thin. I think the best way to sum the game up is its daily challenges. I normally wait until I've 100%ed a game before I review it (because I think you can only really give a fair review of something once you've experienced all of it and Steam achievements are usually a solid benchmark for what "all the content" entails). However, I'm still missing 9 achievements for A Little to the Left. I've played all the base game and DLC content, but those 9 achievements are for the game's daily challenges. Every day, the game wants you to solve one of its puzzles (and these puzzles are, at best, slightly tweaked versions of existing levels, there's nothing fundamentally new about them if you've played the base game). This game does not merit playing daily. It's not interesting enough for me to want to sign onto it every day. But it seems to think it is, because it has achievements for doing so for 100 days.

And its gimmick simply does not have the legs to support the number of puzzles required to justify that price tag. If this game were £10, and it was just the puzzles that are actually good, I'd love it. But for what it actually is - a lot of disappointing filler padding out the diamonds in the rough - there are much better indie games to spend that amount of money on.
